hints.title: Quasi-Stationary Distribution
hints.content:
81: :label: def-qsd-cloning
82: 
83: A measure $\mu_{\text{QSD}}$ is a quasi-stationary distribution if it satisfies:
84: 
85: $$
86: (\mathcal{L}_{\text{Langevin}}^* + \mathcal{L}_{\text{clone}}^*) \mu_{\text{QSD}} = -\lambda_{\text{QSD}} \mu_{\text{QSD}}
87: $$
88: 
89: where $\lambda_{\text{QSD}} \geq 0$ is the **extinction rate** (probability per unit time that the entire swarm dies).
90: 
91: **Interpretation**: The QSD is the stationary distribution **conditioned on survival**. It balances:
92: - Langevin drift and diffusion
93: - Cloning birth-death processes

78: ## 2. QSD as Stationary Distribution
79: 
80: :::{prf:definition} Quasi-Stationary Distribution
81: :label: def-qsd-cloning
82: 
83: A measure $\mu_{\text{QSD}}$ is a quasi-stationary distribution if it satisfies:
84: 
85: $$
86: (\mathcal{L}_{\text{Langevin}}^* + \mathcal{L}_{\text{clone}}^*) \mu_{\text{QSD}} = -\lambda_{\text{QSD}} \mu_{\text{QSD}}
87: $$
88: 
89: where $\lambda_{\text{QSD}} \geq 0$ is the **extinction rate** (probability per unit time that the entire swarm dies).
90: 
91: **Interpretation**: The QSD is the stationary distribution **conditioned on survival**. It balances:
92: - Langevin drift and diffusion
93: - Cloning birth-death processes
94: - Extinction events
